deal_metadata.current_narrative: Although the initial discounts offered by Dell EMC are respectable, NPI considers other external factors when classifying pricing and those areas should be considered in this negotiation.  NPI would typically expect to see both Hardware and Software discounted at 70% - 72% for deal of this size. Discounting at 69.5% places this pricing in the high range (and almost above FMV). ? Due to the timing of this fiscal year-end opportunity, NPI has increased the FMV target discount an additional percentage point, up to 73%. Achieving this target will result in approximately $51K in savings. ? Support is typically 20% of net HW/SW pricing for THREE years. In this offer, NPI finds that the support pricing is at 21% of HW/SW pricing, but only covers TWO years. ©2017 NPI, LLC. All Rights Reserved. NPI Confidential Information. May Not Be Disclosed to 3rd Parties. Page 3 ? NPI adjusted for this anomaly and increases the target discount to 82% of list for support. This discount results in a number that extrapolates out to 21% for the typical three-year term. Successfully negotiating this topic will result in approximately $39K in savings. ? Professional services is a rarely discounted line item and NPI finds that the small discounts that are seen are typically found in large deployments with large amounts of professional services. o NPI believes that these funds ARE somewhat flexible and because of the small dollar amount, NPI is applying the 23% discount that we periodically find in larger deployments to this proposal. Although this equates to a small $2K in savings, NPI mentions it as another negotiation point for Michael Kors.
deal_metadata.description: They just gave a "Special discount" not broken out by type

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Findings and Recommendations NPI reviewed REI?s Kronos proposal and found the pricing for the add-on software subscriptions to be Fair Market Value (FMV) based on comparisons to similar transactions. The pricing for the ?Professional and Educational Services? were noted to be Above FMV.  Pricing Analysis ?	Kronos, having successfully transitioned to a pure software-as-a-service (SaaS) provider, delivered strong growth in the Kronos Cloud last year, with their subscription revenue increasing 45 percent.  ?	Kronos is continuing to add hundreds of customers to the Kronos Cloud (both existing customers with Kronos perpetual licenses as well as new customers).  ?	Kronos also appears to have raised the list pricing for a few products.  ?	As is the case with many other SaaS vendors, Kronos has been re-bundling and renaming several products, as well as adding new features and functionality.  ?	Pricing varies based on factors such as total spend, volume, customer requirements and negotiation leverage, and quantity of perpetual licenses owned by the customers prior to signing up for the SaaS subscriptions.   Workforce Budgeting & Analytics Kronos has a large footprint at REI, but even in the context of larger spend the pricing is very good and appears historical pricing has carried to the current proposal before contract consolidation next year. ?	NPI reviewed current pricing as proposed and determined it to be FMV.  o	While Kronos does not publish list pricing, NPI has numerous deals in our database providing the ability to make comparisons, and by our estimates, your quote is discounted at ~80%+ which NPI considers to be solidly FMV. ?	Market range is typically between $.8 and $1.5 so clearly REI is getting solid pricing given these are add-on purchases.   License Type	Qty	Monthly Unit List	List Extended	Quote Unit Price	Quote Extended	Discount Workforce Budgeting	11,500	$5.42	$62,215	$0.50	$5,750 	91% Workforce Analytics for Retail	11,500	$6.66	$57,500	$0.77	$8,855 	88%  Professional Services Kronos itself bills its consultants in the range of $165 - $215 per hour. Kronos rack rates start at $200 per hour (blended). ?	NPI reviewed current pricing as proposed and determined it to be Above FMV. ?	Currently, your blended hourly rate stands at ~$213, which we would expect for someone with far less of a landscape than what REI has. o	NPI provided target discounts as shown in the table below, returning a nominal additional savings of $1,078 (blended rate of ~$180).  SOW - Role	Hours	Rate	Extended	Discount	Target Discount	Target Price	Target Savings Project Manager	4	$200	$800	0%	10%	$720	$80 Technical Consultant	29	$215	$6,235	0%	16%	$5,237	$998 			$7,035		15%		$1,078  Negotiation Leverage and Strategy ?	NPI recommends REI to express disappointment with these rates. Indicate that you have done your market research (talking to colleagues, or a new REI executive who has experience with Kronos consulting), and you were expecting a blended rate closer to $175 - $180 per hour and to match prior contracts.  ?	Kronos rewards customers for buying add-on software and typically offers better pricing and discounts initially for the add-on subscriptions. While that is evident in the subscription add-on, there is room for improvement on hourly rates.   Determined licenses were FMV but install rates were above FMV with targets provided
deal_metadata.description: Initial ask from REI:  Have a quote for your review.  We are going to add two modules to our Kronos SaaS contract.  These are Analytics and Budgeting.  The second quote combines both and the total costs are listed as monthly fees.  We are looking for a one year contract that will be rolled up in our SaaS agreement next year.  During that time we will look at some multi-year options to see where we can leverage some cost saving.  The first quote is to install Analytics only.  In conjunction with this purchase we are using Axsium to provide professional services to roll out these two modules.  Let me know what you think.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Thanks for checking in, and thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  I ran this past our Microsoft team and we have a bit of feedback for you.  This did not lend itself to a full FMV document, but if you need a more formal document, I can put something together for you.  ?	Overall, the discounting on years 1 & 2, at ~39% is some of the best discounting we?ve seen.  This is a Corporate VP level discount within Microsoft. o	We have other, larger Microsoft clients that are not able to get to that discount level. o	We suspect that a combination of a) your relatively low dollar commit, b) only purchasing Core CAL?s, and c) Chico?s next big purchase will be in 2-years with the EA renewal, makes Chico?s a ?target for opportunity? within Microsoft.  Microsoft will be looking to significantly increase the revenue they get from Chico?s, either by adding on new products, or significantly reducing your discount levels at the time of the EA renewal. ?	It is common that Microsoft is trying to ramp down the 3rd year discount to 20%.  NPI recommends that you push hard for consistency across all 3-years. ?	You will want to be sure to have a ?Not to Exceed? (NTE) clause added to this contract so that the renewal cost does not exceed either CPI or CAGR.  We recommend that you target a NTE 3% increase (over 3-years), but Microsoft will most likely settle on 6% - 10%. ?	Chico?s is receiving solid additional funding in Deployment Funds, CSM, and Fast Track, etc.  There may be even more funding available, but Chico?s would have to tie it to some specific project.  So, overall, Year 1 & 2 pricing are very good.  We recommend that you push for 3rd year consistency and add the NTE.  At that point, Chico?s could move forward with confidence on this purchase.
deal_metadata.description: It has been a while but we have something I would like for you to help provide a FMV analysis on our Microsoft 365 purchase. We are planning on migrating away from Google and to M365 by the end of this year.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed Freddie Mac?s SCE pricing and found it to be above fair market value (FMV) based on comparable Microsoft spends. Discounting is poor in each category for a $2M+ annual spend, and the 0% discount on subscription items is consistent with a 0% rate on subscriptions in Freddie Mac?s larger EAS. The SCE does provide some automatic discounting on perpetual licensing, but at this size of a net spend across multiple agreements, those discounts do not push pricing into the range of FMV.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI strongly recommends not mentioning specific discounts off the Level C reference pricing.  Microsoft is notorious for standing up to requests that solely revolve around discounts; they are typically much more receptive when clients speak to the larger 3-year TCO plus address the financial exposure risks of the SCE?s encompassing licensing rules. ?	NPI recommends getting Microsoft to focus on an even budgetary goal of getting the spend under a $6.75M target for the term ($2.25M annual) in exchange for an expedited deal approval that preserves a March signature timeline. ?	NPI notes that these targets are more conservative to reflect the smaller timeframe available for this deal.  o	More aggressive targets would be appropriate with multiple months available for negotiations, but NPI has seen success even within shorter periods.  o	If Freddie Mac feels the sales team is especially nervous about landing this deal, it is feasible to pursue a more aggressive price target.
deal_metadata.description: Closing remarks: Even with a short month-long timeline, Microsoft upped L/SA, SA, and Subs discounts 6%, 6.5%, and 7% respectively.  Financials and savings reflect the full 3-year spend.    Freddie Mac is reviewing a Microsoft Server and Cloud Enrollment (SCE) proposal set to commence in April 2018.

file_info.name: BOM 10-06-17 AmFam Aruba HPE 7008 203H SD WAN RFP AEBQ2599-J.pdf

deal_metadata.current_narrative: was another iteration in September between Aruba and Meraki.  adding docs  Line item discounts stayed same but got additional reductions. HW $300K.  Subscriptions $1.075M Also some quantities changed but didn't entirely line stuff up.
deal_metadata.description: Please review and provide your input as to the value of the attached quotes.    1.	Cisco Meraki (Pomeroy) 2.	HP Aruba-SD Branch (AE Business Solutions) 3.	Fortinet (Verizon)  Background/Scope of work: AmFam would like to procure an innovative and creative solution that will meet secure WAN, wireless LAN, and network access control (NAC) needs for our sales agency environment.  We will be selecting a technology solution to replace the existing Cisco 891 router, the ASR1004 head end gear, and the existing inline NAC solution.  In addition, we will be deploying wireless LAN to all of the Agent offices.  AmFam will be selecting a vendor to procure the equipment and deploy the technology solution.  At the conclusion of the RFP process we will award a contract.  Additional Information: AmFam has 3,000 agent offices throughout 19 states that will be affected.  We desire to implement a reasonable security protection capability within each office, however, we would like to retain the current Netgear FS728 switches deployed in each office.  Long term, we expect the Netgear will be phased out as we move to a predominantly wireless office.  Use of Aruba ClearPass is desired as the back end authentication system. We want to use a client or dissolvable agent to provide AmFam device posture checks.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: It appeared CNMC was getting a 43% discount and we have seen from 51-57%  I negotiated with Cisco directly and they informed me that he List price had gone up substantially.  Trying to find out if that is true.  They also wanted to couple this with a Wireless project that we had not seen.  CNMC was not happy that they tried to couple any additional concessions with that project and do not think they will award Cisco that deal.  The did ultimately come down another 15K for a month end deal.  Waiting to hear if CNMC moved forward with it.
deal_metadata.description: This ended up getting negotiated with a Wireless deal and more was given on that.

file_info.name: 2018 DR Site  revised TCO Comparison v4.xlsx

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Initial feedback delivered on 3/9.  NPI identified significant cost differences in power.  Suggested Shelter focus on rationalizing power costs before moving on.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: IBM, their path was $2.4, 5 years. Went back to other companies. Looked at all the incidental charges. IBM simplified down to $1.2 and threw in Z13 (were on 196). They are leasing.
deal_metadata.description: Customer submitted an overview (Excel) evaluation on 2/27 but NPI stated that was incomplete and asked for supporting documents.  Supporting documents were sent on 3/5/2018.  Shelter has existing DR data center with IBM in Boulder, CO.  DR costs include both data center cost and mainframe rental.  Shelter solicited bids from IBM for the following: renew and upgrade or bring their own.  Shelter also sought bids from Iron Mountain and Cavern Technologies in Kansas area for data center space only.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Client decided to move forward before we could review.
deal_metadata.description: I hope each of you has been doing well! I would like to partner with you to assist our office in obtaining additional information in our negotiating efforts with SmarterHQ. I would also like to note that our team paid for Storefront services in 2017 for all brands (carved out by the vendor in the amount of $60k). We are not incorporating Storefront in 2018 but have requested the vendor to offer a recoup of those paid costs with the knowledge that we were not using the services in 2017.   I have attached our former agreement along with a renewal proposal for your reference.   Are you able to assist? If so, what is your expected turn around on the request?   Update - we have decided to opt for a one year deal with the assumption that our business will change over the next year. With that, we may not engage your services on this one. Due to the substantial savings we obtained on the prior agreement I don't anticipate, nor do I expect, they will be in a position offer additional savings for a one year renewal. Let me converse with Mark Wheeler first and I will get back to you.

file_info.name: merican Family Insurance June 16 2017 v2 (MIKE EDITS).xlsx

deal_metadata.current_narrative: When it comes to Verint (or NICE or Aceyus or any other major IVR player), you have two opportunities to get your pricing right, new purchases, and significant upgrades, and that is it. During normal renewal cycles, these companies historically do not move and typically raise prices that are not locked in, anywhere from 3-8% year over year.  In fact, I just finished a review, for a large Midwest Bank, that has been a customer of NICE Systems for some 8 years, , and with the exception of last year, when they did a major upgrade, and the first two renewals, where they had contractually agreed to maintenance, NICE raised their rates every year. Why not last year, because they did a major upgrade. Fast forward 365 days to this renewal, absolutely no love what so ever, 3% increase, across the board, that was the extent of their favoritism.  I have reviewed both your prior and current offers. The original offer at 60% was actually not a bad starting position, considering the size of your environment, although, the 3% increase on maintenance right out of the gate and the maintenance rate based on an initial 22% were both above FMV for certain. The 2nd iteration, at 63% discount and a flat maintenance rate, is definitely a step in the right direction. Keep it up.   The goal here should be to get closer to 70%, but that is not going to happen now and it is most likely not going to happen quickly. AFI missed the end of Q2, so you may have to hold 60-70 days to get all the way to 69-70% and it is going to take competition. Even if NICE has been eliminated, they have to be played up. Aceyus is another vendor that you can work into the conversation as is Cisco.   We can help you brainstorm and set this in motion if you need assistance.
deal_metadata.description: We are evaluating On-Premise and Saas WFM solutions with Verint and Nice.  Is this an area you could benchmark?  A month later got this:  We opted for Verints? On Premise model and have been through a few rounds of pricing.  Attached is a breakdown of where we ended up.  Can you benchmark the ?Current? pricing.  They came down on licensing, Professional Services and of course Support and Maintenance from the first pricing breakdown also included on the attached.  Thanks for your help.  No interest in SaaS. Asked about that discount to capture it   Seemed to say he had a verbal for 70% on perpetual but Mike did review and landed at 63%.  From Pat: Revised quote is forthcoming but the one you posted is the latest.   The difference will be a license fees drop from $400K to $367, Support and Maintenance drops from $264K over 3 years to $220,200 and Professional Services drops from $125K (estimated) to $112.5  Yes, this is the key stuff; perpetual current state.  We did look at SaaS and it is cost prohibitive mostly because both Verint and Nices? solution are not true SaaS.  They both essentially are hosted in their own environment.  Got a revised quote (mike excel). Quantities changed a little and support was uplifted but generally ended as-is.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI provided feedback via email. see attached.   Standard support which is included in the Node Pricing vs Premium $0 line item as seen on other quotes.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Based on existing discounts and outcomes that we?ve seen with other clients, NPI finds the FMV range for this purchase is 65% - 68%.  With a current blended discount of 65.7%, VSP is within FMV, but we have seen slightly better discounting and we believe VSP should target 68% for 2,000 Nodes, returning an additional ~$6K in savings.   The message to Chef should focus on dollar figures vs discount percentages.  It is a more convincing argument to explain to Chef that you are trying to reach a budgetary number of $82,250 (using a specific number makes it seem more realistic).  You may be able to rob from Peter to pay Paul and add some additional dollars to the budget for this project, but we are unlikely to get to $94K.  If Chef can meet us in the middle around $85K, approval will likely happen quicker.  NPI is interested in the negotiations that have occurred to this point with Chef?  What has VSP done & said to reach the current 65.7% blended discount?  In sum, NPI feels this pricing is within FMV as is, but 68% is achievable and would be closer to best-in-class.
deal_metadata.description: Hi,  Can you review the quote attached and let me know there is room for price improvement? We already pay $46 for the licenses that we already own and $50 for new licenses.   NOTE from Client: You can close the request for Chef. Another CM was working on that and closed the deal. He appreciated the feedback.  I don't know what that means... closing with "unknown status"

file_info.name: NPI Feedback  NICE VPI to NTR Migration.msg

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI provided formal feedback (see attached). MS had seen solid movement from initial quote but targeted savings based on the early adoption for the new technology.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Closing Notes from MS: here is what I can share:   In the project summary Ian mentioned that ?*NPI Benchmarking data assisted negotiations with NICE, this delivered a further reduction of $350k?.   Based on that, the info you provided certainly was helpful.
deal_metadata.description: Initial ask from MS: Hi Gregg,  Thank you very much for your recent review of our annual VPI Maintenance renewal, as a result of the information you provided we were able to achieve a significant reduction!  As I mentioned at the time, that will be our last year of VPI Maintenance as we begin the migration onto NTR in from Q2/Q3 of this year. With this in mind I would be grateful if you could review the attached NICE quotation? I have had the quote updated to  provide the level of information you usually ask for, of course if you need anything further please let me know.  This is a significant financial commitment and on behalf of my stakeholders would very much appreciate your review.

deal_metadata.description: Do you have benchmarks on SAP Successfactors?  I am actually waiting for a new quote for a 3 year agreement with increased headcount.  Let me know if you will be able to help with this.  I wanted to get it on your radar.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed Cognizant?s rates 3 years ago in 2015 and achieved savings at the time. During the review process, NPI came to understand that many of these resources have a higher/niche/product specific skill set.  Based on this understanding, the target rates we provided are not best-in-class rates but Fair Market Value rates.  For example, for a junior developer in the CA Sunnyvale area, we have seen rates as low as $60 for resources with 0-2 years. However, this may not be a realistic target for Intuit.  NPI recommended a $75 target for IT services - Jr. Developer assuming the resource has 3-6 years of experience and higher skill set and a $80 target for Product development Jr. Developer which requires special product related knowledge.
deal_metadata.description: NO DEAL FINANCIALS. Review of Cognizant's rate card. Estimated spend is approx. $10 - $11M annually

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI provided formal feedback (see attached). MS had seen solid movement from initial quote but targeted savings based on the early adoption for the new technology.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Closing Notes from MS: here is what I can share:   In the project summary Ian mentioned that ?*NPI Benchmarking data assisted negotiations with NICE, this delivered a further reduction of $350k?.   Based on that, the info you provided certainly was helpful.
deal_metadata.description: Initial ask from MS: Hi Gregg,  Thank you very much for your recent review of our annual VPI Maintenance renewal, as a result of the information you provided we were able to achieve a significant reduction!  As I mentioned at the time, that will be our last year of VPI Maintenance as we begin the migration onto NTR in from Q2/Q3 of this year. With this in mind I would be grateful if you could review the attached NICE quotation? I have had the quote updated to  provide the level of information you usually ask for, of course if you need anything further please let me know.  This is a significant financial commitment and on behalf of my stakeholders would very much appreciate your review.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI provided feedback via email, see attached for original and analysis. FMV  Thanks for sending over your quote. Upon review, we determined your current pricing to be FMV as you should feel confident in moving forward.   ?	As it stands, your quantity of 8,450 puts you in 8th pricing group (5,001 ? 10,000).  o	Pricing does get better as you move up groups but there is an obvious increased multiplier making the overall cost higher. o	Since your initial TAPADS purchase in 2016, your YoY increase has consistently remained at ~1%.  Year	Total	Increase 2016	$105,158	N/A 2017	$106,629	1.4% 2018	$107,830	1.1%  ?	Platinum Support is at ~10% of license spend and is considered FMV. o	Proofpoint will include Platinum Support at no charge when bought as SaaS, but not otherwise. This is the case with the current quote and past reviews performed by NPI. This is something to consider as it could result in significant savings across your current landscape.  Description	Part #	QTY	Unit Price	Ext Price Proofpoint Targeted Attack Protection Attachment Defense Virtual Edition	PP-M-TAPADS-V-D-108	8450	$11.60	$98,020 Proofpoint Platinum Support - technical support - 1 year	PP-SUP-PS-12	1	$9,810	$9,810 				$107,830  It is worth considering a consolidation of current contracts under one to allow for more consistent discounting, transparency, and prevent negotiating as frequently. If CAMC really wants to gain the attention of Proofpoint, you should consider a multi-year agreement. In NPI?s experience, CAMC could reduce the year over year costs by as much as 35% with a multi-year commitment with the right messaging and timing.
deal_metadata.description: Rich,  Attached are quotes for our LanDesk and Proofpoint renewals.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the proposed pricing from PCM for Adobe Teams licenses and found the overall pricing to be at FMV (Fair Market Value) compared to similar transactions.   Pricing Analysis ?	Adobe has two main volume programs, the ETLA and the VIP program. NPI more frequently sees the ETLA program than the VIP.  ?	In terms of editions, the Teams licenses are directed towards small and medium businesses and the Enterprise version, which is priced higher, is targeted towards large customers. ?	Michael Kors? current pricing appears to be grandfathered in from prior purchases; the proposed pricing represents a 0% increase in price from the previous year?s pricing.  ?	In terms of discount, the offered discount is 15%, which is at FMV.  o	NPI typically sees discounts ranging between 0% and 15%, with median discounts between 8% and 10%. ?	In summary, Michael Kors can confidently move forward with this purchase as is.
deal_metadata.description: renewal of VIP pricing for Adobe desktop products. 0% price increase from prior year.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Client decided to move forward before we could review.
deal_metadata.description: I hope each of you has been doing well! I would like to partner with you to assist our office in obtaining additional information in our negotiating efforts with SmarterHQ. I would also like to note that our team paid for Storefront services in 2017 for all brands (carved out by the vendor in the amount of $60k). We are not incorporating Storefront in 2018 but have requested the vendor to offer a recoup of those paid costs with the knowledge that we were not using the services in 2017.   I have attached our former agreement along with a renewal proposal for your reference.   Are you able to assist? If so, what is your expected turn around on the request?   Update - we have decided to opt for a one year deal with the assumption that our business will change over the next year. With that, we may not engage your services on this one. Due to the substantial savings we obtained on the prior agreement I don't anticipate, nor do I expect, they will be in a position offer additional savings for a one year renewal. Let me converse with Mark Wheeler first and I will get back to you.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: VSP reduced the counts by a small amount and the discounting actually got worse (from 25% to 18%).    Thanks for sending your KnowBe4 pricing over for NPI to review.  We have seen a number of KnowBe4 purchases as well as pricing from KnowBe4 competitors, so we were able to provide some in-depth comparative analysis.  Please find NPI?s FMV assessment attached.  Let me know if you have any questions or if you would like to discuss on a call.
deal_metadata.description: Chris,  Do you have benchmarks for Knowbe?     Best regards,  Deborah Newton
